questions.question: If an object is moved from Earth to the Moon, its mass will:
options: Increase because it is further from Earth.
questions.explanation: Mass is an intrinsic property of matter and does not change with location.

questions.question: A $5\text{ kg}$ bag of sugar is taken to Mars, where $g \approx 3.7\text{ m/s}^2$. What is its mass on Mars?
questions.explanation: Mass is constant regardless of location. It remains $5\text{ kg}$.

questions.question: Which statement is correct regarding the units used in physics?
options: Weight should be stated in kilograms.
Mass should be stated in Newtons.
Weight should be stated in Newtons.
questions.explanation: Mass is measured in kg, weight is measured in N (since weight is a force).

questions.question: If you double the mass of an object at a fixed location, its weight will:
questions.explanation: $W = mg$. At fixed location, $g$ constant, so doubling mass doubles weight.

questions.question: 'Gravitational mass' and 'Inertial mass' are considered:
options: To be two completely different, unrelated values.
questions.explanation: Experiments show gravitational and inertial mass are equivalent (Einstein's equivalence principle).

questions.question: A $20\text{ kg}$ object is in deep space, far from any planets. Which statement is true?
options: Its mass is $0\text{ kg}$ and its weight is $0\text{ N}$.
Its mass is $20\text{ kg}$ and its weight is $20\text{ N}$.
Its mass is $20\text{ kg}$ and its weight is $0\text{ N}$.
It has no inertia because it is weightless.
questions.explanation: Mass is intrinsic ($20\text{ kg}$). Weight (gravitational force) is nearly $0$ in deep space.

questions.question: When an object is in free fall and gravity is the only force acting on it, its acceleration is:
questions.explanation: In free fall, acceleration = $g$ (independent of mass).

questions.question: Mass is best defined as a measure of an object's:
questions.explanation: Mass measures inertia: resistance to acceleration.

questions.question: Weight is best defined as:
options: The amount of matter in an object
The gravitational force exerted on an object
questions.explanation: Weight = $mg$, the gravitational force on an object.

questions.question: The primary difference between mass and weight is:
options: Mass is measured in newtons; weight in kilograms
Mass is constant; weight depends on location
Weight is constant; mass varies with gravity
questions.explanation: Mass is intrinsic and constant. Weight = $mg$ depends on local gravity.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You clearly understand the distinction between mass and weight.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! Review how mass is constant while weight varies with gravity.
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Focus on the definitions and units of mass vs weight.
scoreMessages.0: Let's review. Study the fundamental difference between mass (inertia) and weight (force).
